title: S.Africa's Implats plans $300 mln equity cash call, FY profit plunges
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Sep 3, 2015, 11:12 BST - UK Markets close in 5 hrs 18 mins S.Africa's Implats plans $300 mln equity cash call, FY profit plunges Reuters - UK Focus â€“ 1 hour 2 minutes ago 
* Impala seeks cash from investors to fund projects 
* Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) punished by the market, down as much as 15 pct 
* Company sees savings of 1.3 bln rand in 2016 (Adds impact of platinum price, analyst) 
By Zandi Shabalala 
JOHANNESBURG, Sept 3 (Reuters) - Impala Platinum (Other OTC: IMPUF - news ) plans to raise 4 billion rand ($299 million) to fund the development of two shafts at its strike-ridden South African operations, the company said on Thursday, news that sent shares tumbling to 12-year lows. 
Investors hammered shares in the world's second-largest producer of the precious metal, sending them down as much as 15 percent before they pared loses to be down 7.2 percent at 43 rand by 0858 GMT. 
Impala, along with rivals Lonmin (LSE: LMI.L - news ) and Anglo American Platinum, is still recovering from last year's record five-month strike that cost the industry billions in lost output, damaged the viability of some mines and led to job cuts. 
Impala said it would use the capital raised, which would be done through an accelerated book-building, to complete two shafts in Rustenburg, the epicentre of last year's strike. 
"We think this is just the beginning and that others, not least of which Lonmin, are also short of capital given the weak PGM market," Investec Securities said. 
The chief executive of its rival Lonmin said last month mines were not responding to cash injections and that investors were unlikely to look favourably on capital requests from mining firms. 
While re-balancing its focus to cash-saving because of deteriorating platinum prices and the effects of the strike, Implats will spend 3.9 billion rand over the next three years on shaft 16 and 20. 
The shafts contain higher grade ore and will help with the more efficient use of smelters due to the elevated quality of the platinum mined and replace ounces lost from older mines. 
"Implats expects both shafts to be value accretive and replace the decline in output from other shafts with cost effective production," it said. 
"It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is critical at this stage to safeguard the completion of key capital projects, the suspension or abandonment of which would have a materially adverse impact on the long term value of the Group," Impala said. 
At the same time Impala planned to shave 1.3 billion rand from 2016 capital expenditure to 4.2 billion rand through closing some unprofitable shafts, increasing output and delaying capital projects. 
Following efforts to return to normal production that were plagued by numerous safety stoppages and operational issues, Implats posted a 58 percent drop in full-year headline earnings per share to 36 cents. 
Headline EPS is widely watched measure in South Africa that strips out some one-off items 
Platinum's spot price is pinned near 6-1/2 year lows just above $1,000 an ounce. 
Gross refined platinum production reached 1.276 million ounces in the year to end-June from 1.178 million ounces last year. 
($1 = 13.3970 rand) (Additional reporting by Peroshni Govender; Editing by William Hardy)
